text.p: These are the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Europe opens the door to Cyprus, but shuts it for Turkey. EU External Affairs Commissioner Hans Van Den Broek says Cyprus cannot be held hostage to Turkish policies.

- The Supreme Court annuls the dismissals of six board members of the state-run electricity authority. Cabinet had suspended all six from duties late last year after reports of alleged irregularities in endorsing tenders for equipment to be installed in a new power station.
- Cyprus President Glafcos Clerides welcomes the European Commission's decision to include Cyprus in the next stage of enlargement talks.
- Young bikers are terrorising Turkish Cypriots in the mixed community village of Pyla in the United Nations controlled buffer zone. The United Nations confirm Turkish Cypriot news reports.
- The French embassy denies holding an official reception in the Turkish-held north.
- The government goes ahead with its illegal decision to assign reservist military officers special duties along the ceasefire line and to patrol well-known areas of crime.

- Ankara is speeding up the proceedures for integration of the occupied areas with Turkey, toughening its stance in reaction to the European Commission's committment to include Cyprus in the next stage of enlargement talks.
- Board members of the electricity authority whose dismissal was declared null and void by the Supreme Court yesterday will demand their tenure continue.
